sections.name: Three Poisons Assessment
sections.description: Explores your relationship with aversion, craving, and confusion.

sections.name: Shadow Detection
sections.description: Explores what's harder to see about yourself.

sections.name: Five Hindrances Current State
sections.description: A check on your current state - what's present right now.

sections.name: Network Topology Indicators
sections.description: How you connect with others - these patterns shape your experience.

sections.name: Risk Vector Assessment
sections.description: Where might your current patterns lead.

sections.name: Speed Round
sections.description: Answer with your gut. First instinct only. Don't think - just respond.

sections.name: Form Differentiation
sections.description: Targeted questions to differentiate between specific forms

questions.text: When someone wrongs you, your most common internal response is:

options.text: Immediate hot rage - I want to hurt them back
Cold calculation - I'll remember this, and they'll pay
Righteous certainty - I'm completely justified in my reaction
Spiraling self-blame - somehow this is my fault
Craving compensation - they owe me something now
Confusion - I don't know what to feel
Problem-solving - how do I prevent this in the future?
Comparison - this proves I'm better/worse than them
Philosophical distance - suffering is part of life

questions.text: Which of these do you find yourself doing most often?

options.text: Snapping at people, then feeling justified
Cutting people off completely - ghosting, blocking, ending relationships
Correcting people - pointing out where they're wrong
Replaying conversations in your head, thinking of what you should have said
Complaining about what you don't have
Zoning out, scrolling, numbing
Trying to understand why things happened
Noticing how you compare to others
Reminding yourself it doesn't really matter

questions.text: The thing most likely to make you withdraw emotionally is:

options.text: Being disrespected or dismissed
Being lied to or manipulated
Being proven wrong publicly
Making a mistake that hurt someone
Not getting what you were promised
Feeling overwhelmed or confused
Losing someone or something important
Seeing others get what you deserve
Being forced to deal with unnecessary problems

questions.text: Honestly, your relationship with anger is:

options.text: It runs me - I can't always control it
I store it - I hold onto grievances
I justify it - my anger is usually righteous
I turn it inward - I'm harder on myself than others
I barely feel it - anger isn't really my thing
It confuses me - I don't always know when I'm angry
I try to understand it - anger tells me something important
I channel it - anger motivates me
I've transcended it - I don't really get angry anymore

questions.text: Your relationship with wanting things is:

options.text: I want intensely and immediately - gratification feels urgent
I want specific things - particular items, experiences, or achievements
I can't name what I want - there's a general emptiness
I want what others have - seeing their success clarifies my desire
I want things but can usually wait or let go
I'm not sure I want much of anything - desire feels muted
I want understanding - to know how things work
I want recognition - to be seen for what I've done
I have what I want - desires feel mostly satisfied

questions.text: Which pattern do you recognize most in yourself?

options.text: I eat/drink/buy/scroll past the point of satisfaction
I research and curate - finding the best version of things
I browse endlessly - looking without committing
I notice what others have that I don't
I enjoy things but can stop when I've had enough
I consume passively - whatever's in front of me
I seek experiences that teach me something
I track my progress and achievements
I have refined taste and access to quality

questions.text: If you're honest, you spend most of your mental energy wanting:

options.text: Physical pleasure or relief - food, sex, substances, comfort
Status markers - money, titles, followers, recognition
Something you can't name - a feeling of fullness or completion
What others have - their success, relationships, opportunities
Progress on meaningful goals
Peace and quiet - to be left alone
Answers and understanding
Victory or vindication
Continued comfort and pleasure

questions.text: Honestly, your relationship with craving is:

options.text: It controls me - I act on urges I wish I didn't
It's sophisticated - I want quality, not quantity
It's vague - I feel empty but don't know what would fill it
It's comparative - I want what would put me ahead
It's manageable - I have desires but they don't rule me
It's dulled - I don't feel strong desires about much
It's channeled - I crave knowledge and growth
It's competitive - I want to win
It's satisfied - I've achieved enough to feel content

questions.text: When you encounter something confusing or complex, you typically:

options.text: Get frustrated and want to destroy or escape it
Look for how to extract value from it anyway
Freeze or shut down - it's overwhelming
Stay with it and try to figure it out
Assess whether engaging is worth your effort
Accept it without needing to understand

questions.text: How well do you understand your own patterns?

options.text: I know exactly what's wrong with me
I'm always discovering new things I want
I'm often confused about why I do what I do
I'm actively working on understanding myself
I know what I need to do to succeed
I've done enough self-work - I know myself well enough

questions.text: When you feel fundamentally lost or uncertain about life, you:

options.text: Get angry - at yourself, others, or the situation
Try to acquire something that might help
Wait for it to pass - feelings are temporary
Investigate - what's this about?
Push harder - action is the answer
Trust it'll work out - it always has

questions.text: Honestly, your relationship with uncertainty is:

options.text: Threatening - not-knowing feels dangerous
Activating - it makes me want to get something
Paralyzing - I tend to freeze when I don't know
Interesting - uncertainty is where discovery happens
Motivating - uncertainty means there's still something to prove
Fine - I've made peace with not-knowing

questions.text: The quality you judge MOST harshly in others is:

options.text: Cruelty - people who deliberately hurt others
Greed - people who take more than they need
Stupidity - people who don't think
Weakness - people who won't help themselves
Arrogance - people who think they're better than others
Negativity - people who complain or bring others down

questions.text: How would your WORST critic describe you?

options.text: Angry, harsh, or mean
Selfish, greedy, or grasping
Lazy, checked-out, or oblivious
Lost, struggling, or broken
Jealous, competitive, or petty
Entitled, spoiled, or out of touch

questions.text: The thing you'd be MOST ashamed for others to know about you is:

options.text: The depth of your anger or resentment
The extent of your desires or cravings
How lost or confused you really feel
How much you're struggling
How much you compare yourself to others
How comfortable your life actually is

questions.text: The story you tell yourself about who you are involves being:

options.text: Righteous - standing up against wrong
Discerning - knowing quality when you see it
Peaceful - not causing problems
Growing - working on yourself
Achieving - earning your place
Blessed - fortunate in important ways

questions.text: Your coworker gets a promotion you wanted. Your FIRST reaction (be honest) is:

options.text: Anger - this is unfair
Wanting - now I need to figure out how to get mine
Acceptance - that's how it goes
Reflection - what can I learn from this?
Comparison - measuring yourself against them
Dismissal - it doesn't really matter to me

questions.text: Someone you respect tells you that you have a significant blind spot. You:

options.text: Get defensive - they're wrong
Get curious about how this might serve you - what's the advantage?
Feel confused and overwhelmed
Thank them and investigate
Evaluate their credibility - are they qualified to judge?
Agree easily - you're probably right

questions.text: Which shadow pattern do you KNOW you have (even if you don't want to admit it)?

options.text: I can be cruel when hurt
I can be greedy or grasping
I can be checked-out or avoidant
I can be self-pitying or victimized
I can be jealous or competitive
I can be entitled or complacent

questions.text: Think of the last time you lied or withheld truth. It was probably to:

options.text: Protect yourself from consequences
Get or keep something you wanted
Avoid dealing with something complicated
Protect someone else's feelings
Make yourself look better
Maintain harmony

questions.text: Right now, how much mental space is taken up by wanting pleasurable experiences (food, sex, entertainment, substances, comfort)?

options.text: Overwhelming - it's most of what I think about
Significant - a major thread in my mental life
Moderate - present but not dominant
Minimal - occasionally arises but passes quickly
Almost none - rarely think about these things

questions.text: Right now, how much mental space is taken up by resentment, irritation, or thoughts about people who've wronged you?

options.text: Overwhelming - I'm frequently angry
Significant - there are several people/situations I'm actively resentful toward
Moderate - some ongoing grievances but they don't dominate
Minimal - occasionally irritated but it passes
Almost none - I rarely feel ill will

questions.text: Right now, your energy and motivation levels are:

options.text: Very low - I can barely do basic tasks
Low - I'm functioning but feel heavy and sluggish
Mixed - some days up, some days down
Adequate - enough energy for what I need to do
High - I feel energized and motivated

questions.text: Right now, your mind is:

options.text: Extremely agitated - can't settle, racing thoughts, high anxiety
Restless - difficulty focusing, jumping between things
Somewhat unsettled - occasional worry but manageable
Fairly calm - can focus when needed
Very peaceful - rarely troubled by restlessness

questions.text: Right now, your relationship with the path forward is:

options.text: Deeply uncertain - I don't know what to do or believe
Questioning - exploring different possibilities
Mostly clear - some uncertainty but general direction is known
Clear - I know what I need to do
Unquestioned - not really thinking about it

questions.text: If you had to pick ONE thing that most blocks your peace right now:

options.text: Wanting things (sense desire)
Anger or resentment (ill will)
Low energy or motivation (sloth-torpor)
Anxiety or worry (restlessness)
Confusion about what to do (doubt)
None of these are major issues right now

questions.text: In relationships, your most common pattern is:

options.text: Intensity - deep connection or total distance, nothing in between
Transaction - I give to get, keep track of exchanges
Merging - I lose myself in others, adopt their preferences
Engagement - genuine interest in mutual growth
Positioning - aware of status dynamics in relationships
Selectivity - small circle, high standards for entry

questions.text: When you learn something important, you tend to:

options.text: Weaponize it - information is power for offense or defense
Hoard it - keep advantages to yourself
Absorb it passively - don't do much with it
Integrate and share - knowledge grows by sharing
Use it to position yourself - demonstrate expertise
Appreciate it - add it to your understanding

questions.text: Your social network is best described as:

options.text: Small and intense - few connections, high stakes
Instrumental - people who can help or be helped
Undefined - you don't think much about it
Selective but genuine - carefully chosen, mutually invested
Strategic - aware of who knows who and how it matters
Established - stable network you've had for a long time

questions.text: When a relationship ends or a connection disappears, you typically:

options.text: Feel it intensely - grief turns to anger or shutdown
Calculate the loss - what did I give that I won't get back?
Move on without much processing - people come and go
Grieve and reflect - what can I learn from this?
Evaluate what it means for your position
Adjust comfortably - you have other connections

questions.text: Under stress, your network of relationships tends to:

options.text: Contract violently - you push people away or they flee
Become extractive - you take more than you give
Freeze - you stop reaching out
Adapt - you ask for help and offer it
Become competitive - you watch for threats
Stay stable - your network can weather difficulty

questions.text: In your networks, you're most often:

options.text: A volatile hub - at the center of drama or intensity
A seeking node - connecting to sources of what you want
A peripheral node - on the edges, not central
A connector - linking people and ideas
A competing hub - aware of other hubs and your relative position
A stable hub - others connect to you

questions.text: If you were going to fall into a trap, it would probably be:

options.text: Righteous anger - being so sure you're right that you cause harm
Sophisticated craving - wanting 'quality' things in ways that still trap you
Comfortable numbness - coasting without growing
Spiritual materialism - treating growth as another achievement
Competitive virtue - being better at being good
Complacent transcendence - using peace to avoid engagement

questions.text: If you keep doing what you're doing, you'll probably end up:

options.text: Isolated by your own intensity
Still hungry no matter what you get
Unchanged in 10 years
Genuinely different in ways that matter
Successful but not satisfied
Comfortable but not transformed

questions.text: The manipulation technique most likely to work on you is:

options.text: Righteous cause - giving you something to fight for
Scarcity - convincing you something is rare or limited
Social proof - showing you everyone else is doing it
Growth opportunity - offering transformation
Status opportunity - offering recognition
Exclusive access - making you feel special

questions.text: The thing most likely to protect you from your worst patterns is:

options.text: Someone who can receive your anger without reacting
Genuine satisfaction - experiencing enough
Something that wakes you up from autopilot
Continued practice and inquiry
Recognition that doesn't depend on comparison
Disruption that forces engagement

questions.text: You find out someone spread a rumor about you.

options.text: Rage
What do I lose from this?
Avoid the situation
Figure out what happened
How does this affect my standing?
It doesn't really bother me

questions.text: You have a free weekend with no obligations.

options.text: Finally some peace - but find yourself ruminating
Think about what you want to do/get/experience
No plans, just drift
Mix of rest and something meaningful
Productive - advance your position
Enjoy comfort and pleasure

questions.text: Someone close to you is succeeding.

options.text: Good for them (but notice some tension)
How can I benefit from their success?
Doesn't really affect me
Genuinely happy for them
Immediate comparison to yourself
Happy from your position of stability

questions.text: You wake up at 3am.

options.text: Anger or replaying conflicts
Wanting - planning acquisitions or experiences
Nothing much - fall back asleep
Reflection or processing
Planning competitive moves
Comfortable - not much disturbs your sleep

questions.text: A stranger is rude to you.

options.text: Anger - internal or external
Confusion about what they wanted
Whatever - move on immediately
Wonder what their deal is
Note their rudeness - they'll regret it
Unbothered

questions.text: You have to make a difficult decision.

options.text: Stress about getting it wrong / being judged
Which option gets me more of what I want?
Avoid deciding as long as possible
Gather information, sit with uncertainty
Which option positions me best?
Trust your gut - it usually works out

questions.text: Something breaks.

options.text: Frustration or anger
How do I get a replacement?
Deal with it later
Fix or accept it
Annoyed if it affects your status
Someone else will handle it

questions.text: You're at a party where you don't know anyone.

options.text: On guard - scanning for threats or judgment
Looking for interesting people to connect with (to get something)
Find a corner, wait for it to be over
Curious - who are these people?
Assessing where you fit in the hierarchy
Comfortable - being new is fine

questions.text: When you sense potential danger or conflict, your first instinct is to:

options.text: Freeze completely and assess
Stay alert but continue what you're doing
Follow what others are doing
Strike first if needed
Work with others to handle it
Slip away unnoticed

questions.text: Your energy level throughout the day tends to be:

options.text: Consistently very low, hard to get started
I save energy, do minimum necessary
Peaks when there's routine/structure
Varies, I go with the group
High when hunting opportunities
Anxious energy, always scanning

questions.text: In social hierarchies, you tend to:

options.text: Stay small, avoid being noticed
Follow the established pecking order
Circle around looking for openings
Work within pack structure
Stay with the group, safety in numbers
Keep distance, observe carefully

questions.text: Your relationship with learning and growth is:

options.text: Active student, always taking courses
Deep questions drive me
Dedicated daily practice
I build and create things
I achieve concrete goals
I seek rich experiences

questions.text: When you think about your current life situation:

options.text: I'm healing from significant wounds
I'm trying but feeling stuck
I'm in survival mode, desperate
I'm comfortable, not much pressure
I'm distracted, going through motions
I'm growing and exploring

questions.text: Your primary mode of engagement with life:

options.text: Inquiry - I need to understand
Practice - I do the work daily
Creation - I make things
Achievement - I accomplish goals
Experience - I taste everything
Study - I learn systematically

questions.text: When you encounter someone more successful than you:

options.text: I want to conquer them
I fight to prove myself
I subtly undermine them
I rank myself against them
I one-up in conversation
I subtly brag about my achievements

questions.text: Your internal narrative about your life often sounds like:

options.text: I've been wronged/victimized
I critically analyze what's wrong
I must accumulate more
Others' success ruins my joy
I must win/conquer
I must fight harder

questions.text: How you track your progress and worth:

options.text: By defeating others
By explicit rankings/metrics
By accumulating credentials/things
By comparison to others
By finding flaws in the system
By counting my victimhood

questions.text: Your relationship with pleasure and comfort:

options.text: I actively pursue maximum pleasure
I've been protected from hardship
I expect things to come easily
I've earned my comfortable life
I'm an expert in my domain
I mentor others from wisdom

questions.text: Your sense of spiritual/personal development:

options.text: I'm beyond ordinary concerns
I live in blissful states
I've transcended suffering
I'm comfortable, don't need more
I was fortunate, born blessed
I enjoy refined pleasures

questions.text: If someone suggested you have blind spots:

options.text: I'd dismiss it, I'm beyond that
Unnecessary, I'm already comfortable
I have expertise, I know
I've earned not having to work on that
That's a harsh judgment
I'd bliss past it

questions.text: When anger arises, the specific pattern is:

options.text: Explosive, everything burns
Targeted, scorching precision
I spread the fire to others
Cold shutdown, frozen rage
Bitter, calculated coldness
Numb, dissociated from anger

questions.text: Your anger tends to:

options.text: Judge and condemn
Execute punishment
Loop endlessly in replay
Turn inward against myself
Burn everything in sight
Freeze everything out

questions.text: Your pattern of wanting/craving specifically involves:

options.text: Insatiable physical appetite
Refined, curated desires
Addictive, compulsive wanting
Collecting status markers
Climbing social ladders
Building influence/following

questions.text: When desire is frustrated:

options.text: I browse endlessly for the next thing
I feel empty, can't name what I want
I covet what others have
I take/steal energy from others
I eat/consume more
I seek another refined hit

questions.text: When you enter a new social or professional environment, you tend to:

options.text: Watch carefully to identify who has power and resources
Quickly assess who might be useful allies or threats
Keep to yourself and avoid drawing attention
Observe quietly to understand the social dynamics
Gradually warm up once you feel comfortable
Engage confidently and make your presence known

questions.text: Your approach to dealing with conflicts or grudges is:

options.text: Wait for the perfect moment to address it on your terms
Confront it immediately when emotions are high
Bottle it up and let resentment build over time
Try to forgive and move on quickly
Obsess over it but never take action
Use it as motivation to prove yourself

questions.text: When you think about your life's purpose, you focus on:

options.text: Reaching specific goals and milestones I've set
Exploring different paths and possibilities
Learning and growing continuously
Finding meaning through spiritual practice
Teaching and helping others develop
Being present and content with what is

questions.text: Your relationship with possessions and wealth is:

options.text: I carefully acquire and organize things I might need
I collect things that reflect my taste or status
I constantly want more no matter what I have
I browse and desire but don't always acquire
I'm content with what I have
Possessions don't particularly interest me

questions.text: When someone else succeeds, your honest first reaction is:

options.text: Immediately comparing their success to my own situation
Feeling competitive and wanting to do better
Pointing out subtle flaws in their achievement
Trying to find ways to surpass them
Judging whether they truly deserved it
Genuinely happy for them

questions.text: When someone comes to you with a problem or question:

options.text: I take time to guide them toward their own answers
I'm eager to share what I know and have learned
I tell them exactly what they should do
I point them to better resources or people
I listen but avoid giving direct advice
I feel uncomfortable being in an authority position

questions.text: Your general state of mind most days is:

options.text: Peaceful and genuinely content with life as it is
Maintaining comfort through careful routines
Subtly proud of my spiritual development
Blissfully unaware of deeper issues
Content but always seeking more knowledge
At peace through dedicated practice
